sn35.87:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn35.87:4.2: Now at that time Venerables Sāriputta, Mahācunda, and Channa were staying on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn35.87:4.3: Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn35.87:4.4: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of solitude, went to Venerable Mahācunda
sn35.87:4.6: “Come, Reverend Cunda, let’s go to see Venerable Channa and ask about his illness.”
sn35.87:5.1: And then Sāriputta and Mahācunda went to see Channa
sn35.87:5.2: and sat down on the indicated seats.
sn35.87:5.4: “I hope you’re keeping well, Reverend Channa; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn35.87:6.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing, not fading, is apparent.
sn35.87:6.2: It feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.
sn35.87:6.3: That’s how severe the winds are piercing my head.
sn35.87:6.4: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. …
sn35.87:6.6: It feels like a strong man’s tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
sn35.87:6.7: That’s how severe the pain is in my head.
sn35.87:6.8: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. …
sn35.87:6.10: It feels like a skilled butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
sn35.87:6.11: That’s how severe the winds are piercing my belly.
sn35.87:6.12: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. …
sn35.87:6.14: It feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
sn35.87:6.15: That’s how severe the burning is in my body.
sn35.87:6.16: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing, not fading, is apparent.
sn35.87:6.17: Reverend Sāriputta, I will commit suicide. I don’t wish to live.”
sn35.87:7.2: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.
sn35.87:7.3: If you don’t have any suitable food, we’ll find it for you.
sn35.87:7.4: If you don’t have suitable medicine, we’ll find it for you.
sn35.87:7.5: If you don’t have a capable carer, we’ll find one for you.
sn35.87:7.7: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.”
sn35.87:8.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s not that I don’t have suitable food;
sn35.87:8.3: It’s not that I don’t have suitable medicine;
sn35.87:8.5: It’s not that I don’t have a capable carer;
sn35.87:8.6: I do have a capable carer.
sn35.87:8.7: Moreover, for a long time now I have served the Teacher with love, not without love.
sn35.87:8.8: For it is proper for a disciple to serve the Teacher with love, not without love.
sn35.87:8.9: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa committed suicide blamelessly.’”
sn35.87:9.1: “I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
sn35.87:9.2: “Ask, Reverend Sāriputta. When I’ve heard it I’ll know.”
sn35.87:10.1: “Reverend Channa, do you regard the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things cognizable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?
sn35.87:10.3: Do you regard the mind, phenomena, mind consciousness, and things cognizable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn35.87:11.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, I regard the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things cognizable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn35.87:11.3: I regard the mind, phenomena, mind consciousness, and things cognizable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
sn35.87:12.1: “Reverend Channa, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
sn35.87:13.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, after seeing cessation, after directly knowing cessation in these things I regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
sn35.87:14.1: When he said this, Venerable Mahācunda said to Venerable Channa:
sn35.87:14.2: “So, Reverend Channa, you should pay close attention to this instruction of the Buddha whenever you can:
sn35.87:14.3: ‘For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
sn35.87:14.4: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
sn35.87:14.5: When there is tranquility there’s no inclination.
sn35.87:14.6: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.
sn35.87:14.7: When there’s no coming and coming, there’s no passing away and reappearing.
sn35.87:14.8: When there’s no passing away and reappearing, there’s no here or beyond or in-between the two.
sn35.87:14.9: Just this is the end of suffering.’”
sn35.87:15.1: And when Venerables Sāriputta and Mahācunda had given Venerable Channa this advice they got up from their seat and left.
sn35.87:15.2: And then, not long after those mendicants had left, Venerable Channa committed suicide.
sn35.87:16.1: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha,
sn35.87:16.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn35.87:16.5: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
sn35.87:16.6: “Sāriputta, didn’t the mendicant Channa declare his blamelessness to you personally?”
sn35.87:16.7: “Sir, there is a Vajjian village called Pubbavijjhana
sn35.87:16.8: where Channa had families with whom he was friendly, intimate, and familiar.”
sn35.87:16.9: “The mendicant Channa did indeed have such families.
sn35.87:16.10: But this is not enough for me to call someone ‘blameworthy’.
sn35.87:16.11: When someone lays down this body and takes up another body, I call them ‘blameworthy’.
sn35.87:16.12: But the mendicant Channa did no such thing.
sn35.87:16.13: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa committed suicide blamelessly.’”
